name: LGTM API specification
description: The REST API for LGTM provides data so that you can customize how you integrate LGTM analysis into your workflow. It includes the following resources:     `/` ([API root](https://lgtm.com/help/lgtm/api/api-v1#LGTM-API-specification-API-root))—get version information or download the specification in OpenAPI format.     `/projects` ([Projects](https://lgtm.com/help/lgtm/api/api-v1#LGTM-API-specification-Projects))—list projects, get a summary of the current status for a project, or add new projects.     `/analyses` ([Analyses](https://lgtm.com/help/lgtm/api/api-v1#LGTM-API-specification-Analyses))—get a summary of results, download all the alerts, or trigger analysis for a specific commit.     `/codereviews` ([Code reviews](https://lgtm.com/help/lgtm/api/api-v1#LGTM-API-specification-Code-reviews))—trigger code review for a patch, and view the results.     `/operations` ([Operations](https://lgtm.com/help/lgtm/api/api-v1#LGTM-API-specification-Operations))—get information about long-running tasks, for example, analyses or code reviews that you've requested.     `/snapshots` ([Snapshots](https://lgtm.com/help/lgtm/api/api-v1#LGTM-API-specification-Snapshots))—download and upload databases representing a snapshot of a codebase.     `/queryjobs` ([Query jobs](https://lgtm.com/help/lgtm/api/api-v1#LGTM-API-specification-Query-jobs))—submit queries to evaluate against existing projects, and download their results.     `/system` ([System](https://lgtm.com/help/lgtm/api/api-v1#LGTM-API-specification-System))—get information on the health or usage of the system.  For an overview and getting started topics, see [API for LGTM](https://lgtm.com/help/lgtm/api/api-for-lgtm).

arguments.name: session-id
arguments.description: The id of the upload session.

arguments.name: repository
arguments.description: The URL of the repository to analyze. LGTM tests this against the [repository providers](https://lgtm.com/admin/help/adding-repository-providers) defined for the system. If it doesn't match any of them, the request fails.

arguments.name: language
arguments.description: Optional, a [language code](https://lgtm.com/help/lgtm/analysis-faqs#which-languages-are-supported) to specify which language to analyze. To request the analysis of more than one language, specify a query  meter for each language. By default, LGTM tries to analyze all supported languages.

arguments.name: mode
arguments.description: The analysis mode of the new project. When set to `full` all commits of the project are analyzed; when set to `sparse` the latest commit of the project is analyzed periodically; when set to `upload`,  no automatic analysis is performed, instead externally-generated databases should be uploaded. For new projects the default value is `full`. The `mode`  meter cannot be used to change the analysis mode of existing projects. Therefore, for existing projects, it should either be left blank or set to match the analysis mode of the project.

arguments.name: commit
arguments.description: Required when `mode=upload`, specify the identifier of the commit used to generate the database.

arguments.name: date
arguments.description: Optional when `mode=upload`, specify the date and time of the commit used to generate the database; defaults to the current time.

arguments.name: worker-label
arguments.description: Optional, any [labels](https://lgtm.com/admin/help/defining-worker-labels) required by workers to analyze this project.  To specify more than one label, repeat the query  meter.

arguments.name: session-id
arguments.description: The id of the upload session.

arguments.name: analysis-id
arguments.description: The analysis identifier.

arguments.name: sarif-version
arguments.description: The desired version of the SARIF format. Currently supported versions are `1.0.0`, `2.0.0`, and `2.1.0`.

arguments.name: excluded-files
arguments.description: Set `true` to include results in files that are excluded from the output by default. This includes results in test code and generated files. For more information, see [File classification](https://lgtm.com/help/lgtm/file-classification).

arguments.name: analysis-id
arguments.description: The analysis identifier.

outputs.name: id
outputs.description: The analysis identifier.

outputs.name: commit-id
outputs.description: The commit identifier. The commit identifier is included only if the same commit was successfully analyzed for all languages. A detailed  eakdown of which commit was analyzed for each language is provided in the `languages` property.

outputs.name: languages.language
outputs.description: The short name for the language.

outputs.name: languages.status
outputs.description: The status of the analysis of this language.

outputs.name: languages.alerts
outputs.description: The number of alerts for this language.

outputs.name: languages.lines
outputs.description: The number of lines of code for this language.

outputs.name: languages.commit-id
outputs.description: The latest successfully analyzed commit for the language. All statistics refer to this commit.

outputs.name: languages.commit-date
outputs.description: The time of the commit.

outputs.name: languages.analysis-date
outputs.description: The time the commit was analyzed.

outputs.name: log-url
outputs.description: A page on LGTM to view the logs for this analysis.

outputs.name: results-url
outputs.description: A page on LGTM to view the results of this analysis.

commands.name: get-analysis-for-commit
commands.description: Get analysis summary for a specific commit

arguments.name: project-id
arguments.description: The numeric project identifier.

arguments.name: commit-id
arguments.description: The identifier of a specific commit. Alternatively, use `latest` for the most recent analyzed commit.

outputs.name: id
outputs.description: The analysis identifier.

outputs.name: commit-id
outputs.description: The commit identifier. The commit identifier is included only if the same commit was successfully analyzed for all languages. A detailed  eakdown of which commit was analyzed for each language is provided in the `languages` property.

outputs.name: languages.language
outputs.description: The short name for the language.

outputs.name: languages.status
outputs.description: The status of the analysis of this language.

outputs.name: languages.alerts
outputs.description: The number of alerts for this language.

outputs.name: languages.lines
outputs.description: The number of lines of code for this language.

outputs.name: languages.commit-id
outputs.description: The latest successfully analyzed commit for the language. All statistics refer to this commit.

outputs.name: languages.commit-date
outputs.description: The time of the commit.

outputs.name: languages.analysis-date
outputs.description: The time the commit was analyzed.

outputs.name: log-url
outputs.description: A page on LGTM to view the logs for this analysis.

outputs.name: results-url
outputs.description: A page on LGTM to view the results of this analysis.

arguments.name: review-id
arguments.description: The identifier for the review (from the `task-result-url`).

outputs.name: id
outputs.description: The identifier for the review.

outputs.name: results-url
outputs.description: A page on LGTM to view the status and results of this code review.

outputs.name: status
outputs.description: The status of the code review.

outputs.name: status-message
outputs.description: A summary of the current status of the code review.

outputs.name: languages.language
outputs.description: The language analyzed.

outputs.name: languages.status
outputs.description: The status for analysis of this language.

outputs.name: languages.status-message
outputs.description: The current state of analysis of this langauge. When available, a summary of analysis results.

outputs.name: languages.new
outputs.description: The total number of alerts introduced by the patch for this language.

outputs.name: languages.fixed
outputs.description: The total number of alerts fixed by the patch for this language.

outputs.name: languages.alerts.new
outputs.description: The number of alerts introduced by the patch for this query.

outputs.name: languages.alerts.fixed
outputs.description: The number of alerts fixed by the patch for this query.

arguments.name: project-id
arguments.description: The numeric project identifier

outputs.name: languages.grade
outputs.description: The grade of the code for this language.

arguments.name: provider
arguments.description: The first part of the URL identifier of a project, which represents the repository host.

arguments.name: org
arguments.description: The second part of the URL identifier of a project, the organization.

arguments.name: name
arguments.description: The third part of the URL identifier of a project, the repository name.

outputs.name: languages.grade
outputs.description: The grade of the code for this language.

commands.name: get-project-config
commands.description: Get configuration for a project identified by numeric identifier

arguments.name: project-id
arguments.description: The numeric project identifier

arguments.name: source
arguments.description: The type of project configuration to retrieve. If this  meter isn't specified, the request retrieves the effective configuration. That is, the configuration that is actually applied to the project, which may be from:   the repository   the administrator-set, project configuration   the global configuration.  If you do specify this value, it must be one of:     `repository` to retrieve the configuration specified by a YAML file in the repository. A 404 status is returned if there is no repository configuration.      `administrator` to retrieve the administrator-set, project configuration. A 404 status is returned if there is no administrator configuration.

arguments.name: limit
arguments.description: The maximum number of projects to return in each response (1-100).

arguments.name: start
arguments.description: An opaque identifier generated by the API.

outputs.name: data.id
outputs.description: The numeric identifier of the project.

outputs.name: data.url-identifier
outputs.description: The URL identifier of the project.

outputs.name: data.name
outputs.description: The display name of the project.

outputs.name: data.url
outputs.description: The full URL of the project on LGTM.

outputs.name: nextPageUrl
outputs.description: The URL to retrieve the next page of projects. Omitted if there is no next page.

arguments.name: project-id
arguments.description: The numeric project identifier.

arguments.name: language
arguments.description: The language of the database to download.

outputs.name: apiVersion
outputs.description: The version number of the API.

arguments.name: project-id
arguments.description: The numeric project identifier.

arguments.name: language
arguments.description: The language of the database to upload.

arguments.name: commit
arguments.description: The identifier of the analyzed commit.

arguments.name: date
arguments.description: The date and time of the analyzed commit (default the current time).

outputs.name: id
outputs.description: The identifier of the upload session

outputs.name: url
outputs.description: The URL for uploading file content.

commands.name: request-analysis
commands.description: Run analysis of a specific commit

arguments.name: project-id
arguments.description: The numeric project identifier.

arguments.name: commit
arguments.description: The identifier of the commit to analyze.

arguments.name: language
arguments.description: The language codes of the languages to analyze. For a list of available languages, see [Supported languages](https://lgtm.com/help/lgtm/analysis-faqs#which-languages-are-supported). To specify more than one language, this  meter can be repeated. If no language is specified, all the project's languages will be analyzed.

commands.name: request-review
commands.description: Run code review for a patch

arguments.name: project-id
arguments.description: The numeric project identifier.

arguments.name: base
arguments.description: The identifier for the base commit.

arguments.name: external-id
arguments.description: Your reference number for the code review.

arguments.name: review-url
arguments.description: An informative back-link to an external system.

arguments.name: callback-url
arguments.description: The callback URL for LGTM to post to on completion of the review. When the code review is complete, the API sends an HTTP POST request to the callback URL with the result of the code review in the request body. The code review results in the request body are identical to the results accessed through the [`/codereviews/{review-id}`](https://lgtm.com/help/lgtm/api/api-v1#opIdgetCodeReview) end-point. If you specify a `callback-secret`, the request also includes an `x-lgtm-signature` header with a digital signature of the request's contents.

arguments.name: callback-secret
arguments.description: The `callback-secret` is used to compute a signature which is included in the `x-lgtm-signature` header of the callback response. The receiver of the callback can check the validity of the response by computing the signature using HMAC-SHA1 and verifying that it matches the `x-lgtm-signature` header value. The HMAC algorithm requires byte sequences as inputs for both the secret and the message. The callback secret string must be converted to bytes using UTF-8 encoding. The response body should ideally be read as a plain byte sequence. Conversion to, for example a JSON object, and back to a byte sequence might change the formatting, and would invalidate the signature.

arguments.name: session-id
arguments.description: The id of the upload session.

commands.name: create-query-job
commands.description: Run a CodeQL query on one or more projects

arguments.name: language
arguments.description: The [language](https://lgtm.com/help/lgtm/analysis-faqs#which-languages-are-supported) you want to analyze.

arguments.name: project-id
arguments.description: The identifier of the project to analyze. Either `project-id` or `projects-list` must be specified.

arguments.name: projects-list
arguments.description: Name of the list containing the projects to analyze. Either `project-id` or `projects-list` must be specified.

commands.name: get-issue
commands.description: Get detailed alert information for an issue

arguments.name: project-id
arguments.description: The numeric project identifier.

arguments.name: alert-key
arguments.description: The alert key is generated by LGTM when it posts an issue `create` webhook request   to an external system using the [issue tracker Webhook API](https://lgtm.com/admin/help/issuetracker-webhook-api).  This key is an opaque identifier that tracks the alert's location over time. For example, if a file containing the alert  is modified, the SARIF data will reflect the updated location of the alert.  Note that the key needs to be URL encoded as it may contain characters that are not web-safe.

commands.name: get-query-job
commands.description: Get the status of a query job

arguments.name: queryjob-id
arguments.description: The identifier of the query job, from the `task-result` given in the response to the initial `POST /queryjobs` request.

outputs.name: id
outputs.description: The identifier for the QueryJob.

outputs.name: result-url
outputs.description: URL to view the result of the query job.

commands.name: get-query-job-results-for-project
commands.description: Fetch the results of a query job for a specific project

arguments.name: queryjob-id
arguments.description: The identifier of the query job, from the `task-result` given in the response to the initial `POST /queryjobs` request.

arguments.name: project-id
arguments.description: The identifier for the project.

arguments.name: start
arguments.description: Start point for the page of results.

arguments.name: limit
arguments.description: The maximum number of results to display (less than 100).

arguments.name: nofilter
arguments.description: Include results that are not part of the source tree. These results are filtered out by default.

outputs.name: next
outputs.description: URL for retrieving the next part of the results (if applicable).

commands.name: get-query-job-results-overview
commands.description: Provide a summary of results for the projects in the query job

arguments.name: queryjob-id
arguments.description: The identifier of the query job, from the `task-result` given in the response to the initial `POST /queryjobs` request.

arguments.name: start
arguments.description: An opaque identifier generated by the API used for pagination.  This identifier will be included as part of the response for this endpoint whenever more than one page of results is available.

arguments.name: limit
arguments.description: The number of results to return. Useful for pagination.

arguments.name: filter
arguments.description: Only return a subset of results. Legal values are `w-results`, `wo-results`, `error`.

outputs.name: data.status
outputs.description: Describes whether the query was sucessfully executed against the project.

outputs.name: data.total
outputs.description: Number of results returned by the query. This is  oken down further into `internal` and `external` results. Only applies if `status` is `success`.

outputs.name: data.internal
outputs.description: Number of results that refer to elements within the source tree. Only applies if `status` is `success`.

outputs.name: data.external
outputs.description: Number of results that refer to elements outside the source tree (e.g., li aries). Only applies if `status` is `success`.

outputs.name: data.error
outputs.description: Error message. Only applies if `status` is `error`.

arguments.name: operation-id
arguments.description: The operation identifier returned on creating the task.

outputs.name: id
outputs.description: The identifier for the operation.

outputs.name: uploads.id
outputs.description: The identifier of the upload session

outputs.name: uploads.url
outputs.description: The URL for uploading file content.

outputs.name: status
outputs.description: Status of the operation.

outputs.name: task-result-url
outputs.description: The URL for the result of the task. For some operations, included only on completion.

commands.name: get-metric
commands.description: Get the computed values of the specified metric

arguments.name: metric-id
arguments.description: The identifier of the metric.

outputs.name: metric-id
outputs.description: The identifier by which this metric is referenced in the API.

outputs.name: measurements.timestamp
outputs.description: The date and time when this metric was computed.

outputs.name: measurements.value
outputs.description: The value of this metric at the timestamp reported.

commands.name: get-metrics
commands.description: Get the identifiers and descriptions of the usage metrics

outputs.name: data.metric-id
outputs.description: The identifier by which this metric is referenced in the API.

outputs.name: data.description
outputs.description: The name by which the metric is listed in the user interface.

commands.name: get-health
commands.description: Get a summary of the application's health
